title: Recent Research on Fasting and Calorie Restriction
editorial: This issue focuses on how fasting, calorie restriction, and fasting-mimicking diets affect brain health, neurodegeneration, inflammation, kidney and cardiovascular function, metabolic adaptation, and chronic disease management. Several studies also highlight that context matters: fasting can be protective, neutral, or harmful depending on physiology, timing, and disease state.

studies.title: Fasting drives key benefits of calorie restriction in Alzheimer’s models
studies.summary: In mice predisposed to Alzheimer’s disease, calorie restriction improved weight and glucose control, but fasting was required to reduce pathology, improve cognition, and activate neuroprotective signaling.
studies.commentary: These findings suggest fasting provides benefits beyond calorie reduction alone.

studies.title: Calorie restriction worsens decision-making after brain injury
studies.summary: In a rat model of traumatic brain injury, calorie restriction aggravated deficits in decision-making and motivation and worsened gut microbiome disruption.
studies.commentary: Calorie restriction may not be universally beneficial in the context of acute brain injury.

studies.title: Time-restricted feeding prevents depressive-like behavior via the gut
studies.summary: In high-fat-diet-fed mice, time-restricted feeding prevented obesity, gut inflammation, brain inflammation, and depressive-like behaviors.
studies.commentary: Circadian-aligned feeding appears to protect mood through gut–brain interactions.

studies.title: Calorie restriction maps protective mechanisms in the aging brain
studies.summary: Using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics across more than 500,000 brain cells, calorie restriction delayed inflammatory cell expansion, preserved neural precursors, and reduced stress and DNA-damage signatures.
studies.commentary: This work provides a molecular atlas of how calorie restriction protects brain aging.

studies.title: Fasting and ketogenic diets in multiple sclerosis
studies.summary: In an 18-month randomized trial, fasting and ketogenic diets did not reduce new MRI lesions compared with a standard diet, but showed exploratory benefits on neurofilament light chain, depressive symptoms, or cognition.
studies.commentary: Dietary interventions may complement multiple sclerosis management, though trial design remains challenging.

studies.title: Fasting-mimicking diets protect against kidney injury
studies.summary: In mouse models of acute and chronic kidney injury, fasting-mimicking diet cycles reduced inflammation, tissue damage, and maladaptive repair.
studies.commentary: Benefits were linked to reduced monocyte recruitment, highlighting immune modulation as a key mechanism.

studies.title: Time-restricted feeding reduces salt-sensitive hypertension
studies.summary: In salt-sensitive rats, time-restricted feeding reduced blood pressure and kidney damage without altering sodium intake or body weight.
studies.commentary: Circadian modulation of feeding may complement sodium management in hypertension.

studies.title: Protein content modifies responses to fasting-mimicking diets in humans
studies.summary: A seven-day fasting-mimicking diet improved weight, glucose, and IGF-1 regardless of protein intake, while higher protein also improved visceral fat, lipid profiles, heart rate variability, and microbiome diversity.
studies.commentary: Macronutrient tailoring may help adapt fasting-mimicking diets to individual goals.

studies.title: Short-term severe energy restriction reverses aging signatures in prediabetes
studies.summary: An eight-week severe calorie restriction in adults with prediabetes reduced inflammatory and senescence-related proteins and improved extracellular vesicle signaling.
studies.commentary: Rapid metabolic improvement may be accompanied by molecular rejuvenation signals.

studies.title: Calorie restriction and exercise in postmenopausal women
studies.summary: Six months of calorie restriction, with or without exercise, reduced fat mass and improved some biomarkers, but paradoxically increased overall physiological dysregulation.
studies.commentary: Weight loss does not uniformly translate into systemic rejuvenation.

studies.title: Organ-level metabolic adaptation to long-term calorie restriction
studies.summary: MRI analyses from the CALERIE-2 trial showed reductions in muscle and adipose tissue mass that contributed to larger-than-predicted drops in energy expenditure.
studies.commentary: Tissue-level changes help explain metabolic adaptation during sustained calorie restriction.

studies.title: Intermittent fasting reduces systemic inflammation
studies.summary: A meta-analysis of 21 trials found intermittent fasting reduced TNF-α, CRP, and leptin, with time-restricted feeding showing the strongest effects.
studies.commentary: Anti-inflammatory benefits depend on the fasting regimen used.

studies.title: NHS low-calorie diet pilot and diabetes remission
studies.summary: A national low-calorie diet program led to an average 10 kg weight loss and diabetes remission in 32% of participants with type 2 diabetes.
studies.commentary: The program is effective but faces challenges related to equity and implementation.

studies.title: Intermittent fasting for Long COVID
studies.summary: In a randomized crossover trial, both mild time-restricted eating and extended fasting improved Long COVID symptoms, with greater reductions after longer fasts.
studies.commentary: Fasting may offer a supportive, non-pharmacological approach for symptom management.

studies.title: Intermittent fasting improves glycemic control in type 2 diabetes
studies.summary: A meta-analysis of 17 studies showed intermittent fasting improved HbA1c and fasting glucose, especially in individuals with higher BMI and better adherence.
studies.commentary: Standardized protocols may help maximize clinical benefits.

studies.title: Intermittent fasting does not disrupt sleep in healthy adults
studies.summary: One week of time-restricted eating had no significant effect on sleep duration, architecture, or subjective sleep quality in healthy individuals.
studies.commentary: Sleep appears resilient to short-term fasting in healthy populations.

studies.title: Repeated long-term fasting in type 2 diabetes
studies.summary: A case report described sustained weight loss, improved glycemic control, and reduced medication needs in a patient undergoing repeated medically supervised long-term fasts.
studies.commentary: The case supports the therapeutic potential of supervised long-term fasting and the need for larger trials.

closing_note: As usual, feel free to comment, raise questions, or share this issue to help spread awareness about the science of fasting.
